Details: There are many types of human coronaviruses including some that commonly cause mild upper-respiratory tract illnesses. COVID-19 is a new disease, caused be a novel (or new) coronavirus that has not previously been seen in humans. View CDC information

On February 11, 2020 the World Health Organization announced an official name for the disease that is causing the 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak, first identified in Wuhan China. The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, ‘CO’ stands for ‘corona,’ ‘VI’ for ‘virus,’ and ‘D’ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus” or “2019-nCoV”. View CDC information

How COVID-19 Spreads

The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, especially those who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet). The virus spreads through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs. How easily a virus spreads from person-to-person can vary. Some viruses are highly contagious (spread easily), like measles, while other viruses do not spread as easily. Another factor is whether the spread is sustained, spreading continually without stopping.

People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic (the sickest). While some spread might be possible before people show symptoms, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Community spread seems to be happening in some geographic areas. ""Community Spread"" means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

More details here from CDC."

Reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases. The following symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure*: Fever, Cough, Shortness of breath. *This is based on what has been seen previously as the incubation period of MERS-CoV viruses. View CDC information
Symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure. This is based on what has been seen previously as the incubation period of MERS-CoV viruses. View CDC information

Fight the stigma

Fear and anxiety about a disease can lead to social stigma toward people, places, or things.

Some groups of people who may be experiencing stigma because of COVID-19 include:

  • Persons of Asian descent
  • People who have traveled
  • Emergency responders or healthcare professionals

How to counter stigma around COVID-19:

  • Speak out against any negative statements directed towards a group of people.
  • Maintain privacy and confidentiality of anyone seeking healthcare or getting tested for COVID-19.
  • Raise awareness about COVID-19 without increasing fear.
  • Share accurate information about how the virus spreads.
  • Provide social and emotional support for people who are connected to the affected areas.

If you are self-quarantined, consider having the following supplies at your home:
  • Hand sanitizer
  • Soap
  • Detergent
  • Dry food
  • Bottled water
  • Rice
  • Proteins
  • Fruits
  • Toilet paper
  • Surface cleaner
  • Dry food
If you have children in your family, consider stocking up on the following items:
  • Milk
  • Snacks of choice
  • Simple board games

How to keep clean

The simplest steps to practice good hygiene for yourself and your household

  1. Don't touch your face.
  2. Clean your hands often. Check out the video below.
  3. Avoid close contact, especially with sick people.
  4. Practice social distancing.
  5. Cover your mouth when coughing.
  6. Throw away used tissues.
  7. Stock up on supplies.
  8. If using food or grocery delivery, leave a note at door to tell the driver to leave the delivery at the door.
  9. Clean and disinfect surfaces regularly.
  10. Stay home if you have any signs of sickness
